Description: Limestone block from tomb-relief: depicting the legs of the deceased and wife and the heads of two offering-bearers. The overall scene on this wall is occupied by a representation of the owner of the tomb and his wife; he is shown wearing a leopard-skin and holding a staff of office. A small lower register contains the figures of three offering-bearers who are shown bringing offerings of vessels, meat, and birds. There are no inscriptions. The stone is soft and the surfaces of the individual blocks have suffered much flaking through the action of salt. No colour is preserved.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: The British Museum, 'Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum' Part 6 (London, 1922), pl. 13.
Bibliographic references: James 1961 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc. Part 1 (pl.23)
Condition: Poor; incomplete. The stone is soft and the surfaces of the individual blocks have suffered much flaking through the action of salt. No colour is preserved.
Acquisition name: Purchased from: R J Moss & Co
